speaker: PROSPERO
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: PROSPERO
text_entry: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.

speaker: PROSPERO
text_entry: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Good day, sir.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: I am glad you're well.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: I have not seen you long: how goes the world?

speaker: Painter
text_entry: It wears, sir, as it grows.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Ay, that's well known:

speaker: Poet
text_entry: But what particular rarity? what strange,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Which manifold record not matches? See,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Magic of bounty! all these spirits thy power

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Hath conjured to attend. I know the merchant.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: I know them both; th' other's a jeweller.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: O, 'tis a worthy lord.

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: Nay, that's most fix'd.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: A most incomparable man, breathed, as it were,

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: To an untirable and continuate goodness:

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: He passes.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: Jeweller: I have a jewel here--

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: O, pray, let's see't: for the Lord Timon, sir?

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: Jeweller: If he will touch the estimate: but, for that--

speaker: Poet
text_entry: [Reciting to himself]  'When we for recompense have

speaker: Poet
text_entry: praised the vile,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: It stains the glory in that happy verse

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Which aptly sings the good.'

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: 'Tis a good form.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: Looking at the jewel

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: And rich: here is a water, look ye.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedication

speaker: Painter
text_entry: To the great lord.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: A thing slipp'd idly from me.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Our poesy is as a gum, which oozes

speaker: Poet
text_entry: From whence 'tis nourish'd: the fire i' the flint

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Shows not till it be struck; our gentle flame

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Provokes itself and like the current flies

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Each bound it chafes. What have you there?

speaker: Painter
text_entry: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Let's see your piece.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: 'Tis a good piece.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: So 'tis: this comes off well and excellent.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Indifferent.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Admirable: how this grace

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Speaks his own standing! what a mental power

speaker: Poet
text_entry: This eye shoots forth! how big imagination

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Moves in this lip! to the dumbness of the gesture

speaker: Poet
text_entry: One might interpret.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: It is a pretty mocking of the life.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Here is a touch; is't good?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: I will say of it,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: It tutors nature: artificial strife

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Lives in these touches, livelier than life.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Enter certain Senators, and pass over

speaker: Painter
text_entry: How this lord is follow'd!

speaker: Poet
text_entry: The senators of Athens: happy man!

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Look, more!

speaker: Poet
text_entry: You see this confluence, this great flood

speaker: Poet
text_entry: of visitors.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: I have, in this rough work, shaped out a man,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug

speaker: Poet
text_entry: With amplest entertainment: my free drift

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Halts not particularly, but moves itself

speaker: Poet
text_entry: In a wide sea of wax: no levell'd malice

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Infects one comma in the course I hold;

speaker: Poet
text_entry: But flies an eagle flight, bold and forth on,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Leaving no tract behind.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: How shall I understand you?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: I will unbolt to you.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: You see how all conditions, how all minds,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: As well of glib and slippery creatures as

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Of grave and austere quality, tender down

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Their services to Lord Timon: his large fortune

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Upon his good and gracious nature hanging

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Subdues and properties to his love and tendance

speaker: Poet
text_entry: All sorts of hearts; yea, from the glass-faced flatterer

speaker: Poet
text_entry: To Apemantus, that few things loves better

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Than to abhor himself: even he drops down

speaker: Poet
text_entry: The knee before him, and returns in peace

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Most rich in Timon's nod.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: I saw them speak together.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Feign'd Fortune to be throned: the base o' the mount

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Is rank'd with all deserts, all kind of natures,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: That labour on the bosom of this sphere

speaker: Poet
text_entry: To propagate their states: amongst them all,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fix'd,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: One do I personate of Lord Timon's frame,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Whom Fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her;

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Whose present grace to present slaves and servants

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Translates his rivals.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: 'Tis conceived to scope.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks,

speaker: Painter
text_entry: With one man beckon'd from the rest below,

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Bowing his head against the sleepy mount

speaker: Painter
text_entry: To climb his happiness, would be well express'd

speaker: Painter
text_entry: In our condition.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Nay, sir, but hear me on.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: All those which were his fellows but of late,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Some better than his value, on the moment

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Rain sacrificial whisperings in his ear,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Drink the free air.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Ay, marry, what of these?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Which labour'd after him to the mountain's top

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Not one accompanying his declining foot.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: 'Tis common:

speaker: Painter
text_entry: A thousand moral paintings I can show

speaker: Painter
text_entry: That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune's

speaker: Painter
text_entry: More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well

speaker: Painter
text_entry: To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen

speaker: Painter
text_entry: The foot above the head.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself  courteously to every suitor; a Messenger from  VENTIDIUS talking with him; LUCILIUS and other servants following

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Imprison'd is he, say you?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Ay, my good lord: five talents is his debt,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: His means most short, his creditors most strait:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Your honourable letter he desires

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To those have shut him up; which failing,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Periods his comfort.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Noble Ventidius! Well;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I am not of that feather to shake off

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: My friend when he must need me. I do know him

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A gentleman that well deserves a help:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Which he shall have: I'll pay the debt,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: and free him.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Your lordship ever binds him.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Commend me to him: I will send his ransom;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And being enfranchised, bid him come to me.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: 'Tis not enough to help the feeble up,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But to support him after. Fare you well.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: All happiness to your honour!

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enter an old Athenian

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Freely, good father.

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I have so: what of him?

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Attends he here, or no? Lucilius!

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Here, at your lordship's service.

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: By night frequents my house. I am a man

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: That from my first have been inclined to thrift;

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: And my estate deserves an heir more raised

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Than one which holds a trencher.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Well; what further?

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: One only daughter have I, no kin else,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: On whom I may confer what I have got:

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: The maid is fair, o' the youngest for a bride,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: And I have bred her at my dearest cost

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: In qualities of the best. This man of thine

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Attempts her love: I prithee, noble lord,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Join with me to forbid him her resort;

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Myself have spoke in vain.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The man is honest.

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Therefore he will be, Timon:

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: His honesty rewards him in itself;

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: It must not bear my daughter.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Does she love him?

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: She is young and apt:

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Our own precedent passions do instruct us

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: What levity's in youth.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: [To LUCILIUS]           Love you the maid?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: If in her marriage my consent be missing,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: I call the gods to witness, I will choose

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: And dispossess her all.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How shall she be endow'd,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: if she be mated with an equal husband?

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Three talents on the present; in future, all.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: This gentleman of mine hath served me long:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To build his fortune I will strain a little,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For 'tis a bond in men. Give him thy daughter:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What you bestow, in him I'll counterpoise,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And make him weigh with her.

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Most noble lord,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Pawn me to this your honour, she is his.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: My hand to thee; mine honour on my promise.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Humbly I thank your lordship: never may

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: The state or fortune fall into my keeping,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Which is not owed to you!

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Exeunt LUCILIUS and Old Athenian

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Vouchsafe my labour, and long live your lordship!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I thank you; you shall hear from me anon:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go not away. What have you there, my friend?

speaker: Painter
text_entry: A piece of painting, which I do beseech

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Your lordship to accept.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Painting is welcome.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The painting is almost the natural man;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: or since dishonour traffics with man's nature,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: He is but outside: these pencill'd figures are

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Even such as they give out. I like your work;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And you shall find I like it: wait attendance

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Till you hear further from me.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: The gods preserve ye!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Well fare you, gentleman: give me your hand;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: We must needs dine together. Sir, your jewel

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Hath suffer'd under praise.

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: What, my lord! dispraise?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A more satiety of commendations.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If I should pay you for't as 'tis extoll'd,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: It would unclew me quite.

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: My lord, 'tis rated

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: As those which sell would give: but you well know,

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: Things of like value differing in the owners

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: Are prized by their masters: believe't, dear lord,

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: You mend the jewel by the wearing it.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Well mock'd.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: No, my good lord; he speaks the common tongue,

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: Which all men speak with him.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Look, who comes here: will you be chid?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter APEMANTUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Jeweller: We'll bear, with your lordship.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: He'll spare none.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Good morrow to thee, gentle Apemantus!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: When thou art Timon's dog, and these knaves honest.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Why dost thou call them knaves? thou know'st them not.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Are they not Athenians?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Yes.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Then I repent not.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Jeweller: You know me, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou know'st I do: I call'd thee by thy name.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou art proud, Apemantus.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Whither art going?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To knock out an honest Athenian's brains.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That's a deed thou'lt die for.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Right, if doing nothing be death by the law.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How likest thou this picture, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: The best, for the innocence.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Wrought he not well that painted it?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: He wrought better that made the painter; and yet

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: he's but a filthy piece of work.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: You're a dog.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thy mother's of my generation: what's she, if I be a dog?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No; I eat not lords.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: An thou shouldst, thou 'ldst anger ladies.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: O, they eat lords; so they come by great bellies.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That's a lascivious apprehension.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: So thou apprehendest it: take it for thy labour.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Not so well as plain-dealing, which will not cost a

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: man a doit.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What dost thou think 'tis worth?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Not worth my thinking. How now, poet!

speaker: Poet
text_entry: How now, philosopher!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou liest.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Art not one?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Yes.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Then I lie not.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Art not a poet?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Yes.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Then thou liest: look in thy last work, where thou

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: hast feigned him a worthy fellow.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: That's not feigned; he is so.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thy

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: labour: he that loves to be flattered is worthy o'

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: the flatterer. Heavens, that I were a lord!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What wouldst do then, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: E'en as Apemantus does now; hate a lord with my heart.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What, thyself?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ay.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Wherefore?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That I had no angry wit to be a lord.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Art not thou a merchant?

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: Ay, Apemantus.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Traffic confound thee, if the gods will not!

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Traffic's thy god; and thy god confound thee!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Trumpet sounds. Enter a Messenger

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What trumpet's that?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: 'Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: All of companionship.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Pray, entertain them; give them guide to us.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exeunt some Attendants

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You must needs dine with me: go not you hence

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Till I have thank'd you: when dinner's done,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Show me this piece. I am joyful of your sights.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter ALCIBIADES, with the rest

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Most welcome, sir!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: So, so, there!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Aches contract and starve your supple joints!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That there should be small love 'mongst these

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: sweet knaves,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: And all this courtesy! The strain of man's bred out

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Into baboon and monkey.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feed

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Most hungerly on your sight.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Right welcome, sir!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ere we depart, we'll share a bounteous time

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: In different pleasures. Pray you, let us in.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exeunt all except APEMANTUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter two Lords

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: What time o' day is't, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Time to be honest.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That time serves still.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: The more accursed thou, that still omitt'st it.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Thou art going to Lord Timon's feast?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ay, to see meat fill knaves and wine heat fools.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Why, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Shouldst have kept one to thyself, for I mean to

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: give thee none.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Hang thyself!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding: make thy

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: requests to thy friend.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Away, unpeaceable dog, or I'll spurn thee hence!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I will fly, like a dog, the heels o' the ass.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: He's opposite to humanity. Come, shall we in,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And taste Lord Timon's bounty? he outgoes

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The very heart of kindness.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: He pours it out; Plutus, the god of gold,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Is but his steward: no meed, but he repays

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Sevenfold above itself; no gift to him,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: But breeds the giver a return exceeding

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: All use of quittance.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The noblest mind he carries

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That ever govern'd man.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Long may he live in fortunes! Shall we in?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I'll keep you company.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Hautboys playing loud music. A great banquet  served in; FLAVIUS and others attending; then enter  TIMON, ALCIBIADES, Lords, Senators, and VENTIDIUS.  Then comes, dropping, after all, APEMANTUS, discontentedly, like himself

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Most honour'd Timon,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: It hath pleased the gods to remember my father's age,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: And call him to long peace.

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: He is gone happy, and has left me rich:

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Then, as in grateful virtue I am bound

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: To your free heart, I do return those talents,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Doubled with thanks and service, from whose help

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: I derived liberty.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: O, by no means,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Honest Ventidius; you mistake my love:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I gave it freely ever; and there's none

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Can truly say he gives, if he receives:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If our betters play at that game, we must not dare

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To imitate them; faults that are rich are fair.

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: A noble spirit!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Nay, my lords,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They all stand ceremoniously looking on TIMON

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ceremony was but devised at first

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To set a gloss on faint deeds, hollow welcomes,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Recanting goodness, sorry ere 'tis shown;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But where there is true friendship, there needs none.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Pray, sit; more welcome are ye to my fortunes

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Than my fortunes to me.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They sit

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: My lord, we always have confess'd it.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ho, ho, confess'd it! hang'd it, have you not?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: O, Apemantus, you are welcome.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: You shall not make me welcome:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Fie, thou'rt a churl; ye've got a humour there

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Does not become a man: 'tis much to blame.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They say, my lords, 'ira furor brevis est;' but yond

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: man is ever angry. Go, let him have a table by

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: himself, for he does neither affect company, nor is

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: he fit for't, indeed.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon: I come to

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: observe; I give thee warning on't.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I take no heed of thee; thou'rt an Athenian,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: therefore welcome: I myself would have no power;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: prithee, let my meat make thee silent.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I scorn thy meat; 'twould choke me, for I should

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: ne'er flatter thee. O you gods, what a number of

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: men eat Timon, and he sees 'em not! It grieves me

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: to see so many dip their meat in one man's blood;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: and all the madness is, he cheers them up too.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I wonder men dare trust themselves with men:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Methinks they should invite them without knives;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Good for their meat, and safer for their lives.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: There's much example for't; the fellow that sits

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: next him now, parts bread with him, pledges the

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: breath of him in a divided draught, is the readiest

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: man to kill him: 't has been proved. If I were a

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: huge man, I should fear to drink at meals;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Lest they should spy my windpipe's dangerous notes:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Great men should drink with harness on their throats.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: My lord, in heart; and let the health go round.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Flow this way! A brave fellow! he keeps his tides

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: well. Those healths will make thee and thy state

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: look ill, Timon. Here's that which is too weak to

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: be a sinner, honest water, which ne'er left man i' the mire:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: This and my food are equals; there's no odds:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Apemantus' grace.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Immortal gods, I crave no pelf;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I pray for no man but myself:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Grant I may never prove so fond,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To trust man on his oath or bond;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Or a harlot, for her weeping;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Or a dog, that seems a-sleeping:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Or a keeper with my freedom;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Or my friends, if I should need 'em.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Amen. So fall to't:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Rich men sin, and I eat root.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Eats and drinks

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Much good dich thy good heart, Apemantus!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Captain Alcibiades, your heart's in the field now.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than a

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: dinner of friends.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: So the were bleeding-new, my lord, there's no meat

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: like 'em: I could wish my best friend at such a feast.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Would all those fatterers were thine enemies then,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: that then thou mightst kill 'em and bid me to 'em!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Might we but have that happiness, my lord, that you

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: would once use our hearts, whereby we might express

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: some part of our zeals, we should think ourselves

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: for ever perfect.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: O, no doubt, my good friends, but the gods

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: themselves have provided that I shall have much help

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: from you: how had you been my friends else? why

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: have you that charitable title from thousands, did

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: not you chiefly belong to my heart? I have told

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: more of you to myself than you can with modesty

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: speak in your own behalf; and thus far I confirm

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: you. O you gods, think I, what need we have any

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: friends, if we should ne'er have need of 'em? they

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: were the most needless creatures living, should we

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: ne'er have use for 'em, and would most resemble

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: sweet instruments hung up in cases that keep their

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: sounds to themselves. Why, I have often wished

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: myself poorer, that I might come nearer to you. We

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: are born to do benefits: and what better or

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: properer can we can our own than the riches of our

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: friends? O, what a precious comfort 'tis, to have

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: so many, like brothers, commanding one another's

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: fortunes! O joy, e'en made away ere 't can be born!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Mine eyes cannot hold out water, methinks: to

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: forget their faults, I drink to you.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou weepest to make them drink, Timon.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Joy had the like conception in our eyes

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: And at that instant like a babe sprung up.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: I promise you, my lord, you moved me much.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Much!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Tucket, within

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What means that trump?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How now?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Please you, my lord, there are certain

speaker: Servant
text_entry: ladies most desirous of admittance.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ladies! what are their wills?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: There comes with them a forerunner, my lord, which

speaker: Servant
text_entry: bears that office, to signify their pleasures.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I pray, let them be admitted.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter Cupid

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: That of his bounties taste! The five best senses

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: Acknowledge thee their patron; and come freely

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: To gratulate thy plenteous bosom: th' ear,

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: Taste, touch and smell, pleased from thy tale rise;

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: They only now come but to feast thine eyes.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They're welcome all; let 'em have kind admittance:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Music, make their welcome!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit Cupid

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: You see, my lord, how ample you're beloved.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Music. Re-enter Cupid with a mask of Ladies  as Amazons, with lutes in their hands, dancing and playing

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Hoy-day, what a sweep of vanity comes this way!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: They dance! they are mad women.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Like madness is the glory of this life.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: As this pomp shows to a little oil and root.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: We make ourselves fools, to disport ourselves;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: And spend our flatteries, to drink those men

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Upon whose age we void it up again,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: With poisonous spite and envy.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Who lives that's not depraved or depraves?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Who dies, that bears not one spurn to their graves

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Of their friends' gift?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I should fear those that dance before me now

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Would one day stamp upon me: 't has been done;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Men shut their doors against a setting sun.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of  TIMON; and to show their loves, each singles out an  Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hautboys, and cease

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You have done our pleasures much grace, fair ladies,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Set a fair fashion on our entertainment,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Which was not half so beautiful and kind;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You have added worth unto 't and lustre,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And entertain'd me with mine own device;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I am to thank you for 't.

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: My lord, you take us even at the best.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: 'Faith, for the worst is filthy; and would not hold

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: taking, I doubt me.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Please you to dispose yourselves.

speaker: All Ladies
text_entry: Most thankfully, my lord.

speaker: All Ladies
text_entry: Exeunt Cupid and Ladies

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Flavius.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The little casket bring me hither.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Yes, my lord. More jewels yet!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: There is no crossing him in 's humour;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Aside

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Else I should tell him,--well, i' faith I should,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: When all's spent, he 'ld be cross'd then, an he could.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: 'Tis pity bounty had not eyes behind,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That man might ne'er be wretched for his mind.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Where be our men?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Here, my lord, in readiness.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Our horses!

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Re-enter FLAVIUS, with the casket

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: O my friends,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I have one word to say to you: look you, my good lord,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I must entreat you, honour me so much

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: As to advance this jewel; accept it and wear it,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Kind my lord.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I am so far already in your gifts,--

speaker: All
text_entry: So are we all.

speaker: All
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: Servant
text_entry: My lord, there are certain nobles of the senate

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Newly alighted, and come to visit you.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They are fairly welcome.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I beseech your honour,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Vouchsafe me a word; it does concern you near.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Near! why then, another time I'll hear thee:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I prithee, let's be provided to show them

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: entertainment.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: [Aside]  I scarce know how.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Enter a Second Servant

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: May it please your honour, Lord Lucius,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Out of his free love, hath presented to you

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Four milk-white horses, trapp'd in silver.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I shall accept them fairly; let the presents

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be worthily entertain'd.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter a third Servant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How now! what news?

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Please you, my lord, that honourable

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: gentleman, Lord Lucullus, entreats your company

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: to-morrow to hunt with him, and has sent your honour

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: two brace of greyhounds.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll hunt with him; and let them be received,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Not without fair reward.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: [Aside]                What will this come to?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: He commands us to provide, and give great gifts,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And all out of an empty coffer:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Nor will he know his purse, or yield me this,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To show him what a beggar his heart is,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Being of no power to make his wishes good:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: His promises fly so beyond his state

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That what he speaks is all in debt; he owes

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: For every word: he is so kind that he now

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Pays interest for 't; his land's put to their books.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Well, would I were gently put out of office

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Before I were forced out!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Happier is he that has no friend to feed

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Than such that do e'en enemies exceed.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I bleed inwardly for my lord.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You do yourselves

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Much wrong, you bate too much of your own merits:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Here, my lord, a trifle of our love.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: With more than common thanks I will receive it.

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: O, he's the very soul of bounty!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And now I remember, my lord, you gave

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Good words the other day of a bay courser

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I rode on: it is yours, because you liked it.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: O, I beseech you, pardon me, my lord, in that.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You may take my word, my lord; I know, no man

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Can justly praise but what he does affect:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I weigh my friend's affection with mine own;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll tell you true. I'll call to you.

speaker: All Lords
text_entry: O, none so welcome.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I take all and your several visitations

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: So kind to heart, 'tis not enough to give;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Methinks, I could deal kingdoms to my friends,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And ne'er be weary. Alcibiades,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: It comes in charity to thee: for all thy living

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Is 'mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Lie in a pitch'd field.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Ay, defiled land, my lord.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: We are so virtuously bound--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And so

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Am I to you.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: So infinitely endear'd--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: All to you. Lights, more lights!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The best of happiness,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Honour and fortunes, keep with you, Lord Timon!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ready for his friends.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exeunt all but APEMANTUS and TIMON

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: What a coil's here!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Serving of becks and jutting-out of bums!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That are given for 'em. Friendship's full of dregs:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Methinks, false hearts should never have sound legs,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on court'sies.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Now, Apemantus, if thou wert not sullen, I would be

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: good to thee.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No, I'll nothing: for if I should be bribed too,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: there would be none left to rail upon thee, and then

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: thou wouldst sin the faster. Thou givest so long,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Timon, I fear me thou wilt give away thyself in

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: paper shortly: what need these feasts, pomps and

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: vain-glories?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Nay, an you begin to rail on society once, I am

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: sworn not to give regard to you. Farewell; and come

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: with better music.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: So:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou wilt not hear me now; thou shalt not then:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I'll lock thy heaven from thee.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: O, that men's ears should be

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To counsel deaf, but not to flattery!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: SCENE I. A Senator's house.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Enter Senator, with papers in his hand

speaker: Senator
text_entry: And late, five thousand: to Varro and to Isidore

speaker: Senator
text_entry: He owes nine thousand; besides my former sum,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Which makes it five and twenty. Still in motion

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Of raging waste? It cannot hold; it will not.

speaker: Senator
text_entry: If I want gold, steal but a beggar's dog,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: And give it Timon, why, the dog coins gold.

speaker: Senator
text_entry: If I would sell my horse, and buy twenty more

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Better than he, why, give my horse to Timon,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Ask nothing, give it him, it foals me, straight,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: And able horses. No porter at his gate,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: But rather one that smiles and still invites

speaker: Senator
text_entry: All that pass by. It cannot hold: no reason

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Can found his state in safety. Caphis, ho!

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Caphis, I say!

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Enter CAPHIS

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Here, sir; what is your pleasure?

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Get on your cloak, and haste you to Lord Timon;

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Importune him for my moneys; be not ceased

speaker: Senator
text_entry: With slight denial, nor then silenced when--

speaker: Senator
text_entry: 'Commend me to your master'--and the cap

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Plays in the right hand, thus: but tell him,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: My uses cry to me, I must serve my turn

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Out of mine own; his days and times are past

speaker: Senator
text_entry: And my reliances on his fracted dates

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Have smit my credit: I love and honour him,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: But must not break my back to heal his finger;

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Immediate are my needs, and my relief

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Must not be toss'd and turn'd to me in words,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: But find supply immediate. Get you gone:

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Put on a most importunate aspect,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: A visage of demand; for, I do fear,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: When every feather sticks in his own wing,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Lord Timon will be left a naked gull,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Which flashes now a phoenix. Get you gone.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: I go, sir.

speaker: Senator
text_entry: 'I go, sir!'--Take the bonds along with you,

speaker: Senator
text_entry: And have the dates in contempt.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: I will, sir.

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Go.

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Senator
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. A hall in Timon's house.

speaker: Senator
text_entry: Enter FLAVIUS, with many bills in his hand

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: No care, no stop! so senseless of expense,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That he will neither know how to maintain it,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Nor cease his flow of riot: takes no account

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: How things go from him, nor resumes no care

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Of what is to continue: never mind

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Was to be so unwise, to be so kind.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: What shall be done? he will not hear, till feel:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I must be round with him, now he comes from hunting.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Fie, fie, fie, fie!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of Isidore and Varro

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Good even, Varro: what,

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: You come for money?

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Varro's Servant Is't not your business too?

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: It is: and yours too, Isidore?

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Isidore's Servant It is so.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Would we were all discharged!

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Varro's Servant I fear it.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Here comes the lord.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Enter TIMON, ALCIBIADES, and Lords,  and c

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: So soon as dinner's done, we'll forth again,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: My Alcibiades. With me? what is your will?

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: My lord, here is a note of certain dues.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Dues! Whence are you?

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Of Athens here, my lord.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go to my steward.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Please it your lordship, he hath put me off

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: To the succession of new days this month:

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: My master is awaked by great occasion

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: To call upon his own, and humbly prays you

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: That with your other noble parts you'll suit

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: In giving him his right.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Mine honest friend,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I prithee, but repair to me next morning.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Nay, good my lord,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Contain thyself, good friend.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Varro's Servant One Varro's servant, my good lord,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Isidore's Servant From Isidore;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: He humbly prays your speedy payment.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: If you did know, my lord, my master's wants--

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Varro's Servant 'Twas due on forfeiture, my lord, six weeks And past.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Isidore's Servant          Your steward puts me off, my lord;

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: And I am sent expressly to your lordship.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Give me breath.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I do beseech you, good my lords, keep on;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll wait upon you instantly.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exeunt ALCIBIADES and Lords

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To FLAVIUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Come hither: pray you,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How goes the world, that I am thus encounter'd

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: With clamourous demands of date-broke bonds,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And the detention of long-since-due debts,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Against my honour?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Please you, gentlemen,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The time is unagreeable to this business:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Your importunacy cease till after dinner,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That I may make his lordship understand

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Wherefore you are not paid.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Do so, my friends. See them well entertain'd.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Pray, draw near.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Enter APEMANTUS and Fool

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Stay, stay, here comes the fool with Apemantus:

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: let's ha' some sport with 'em.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Varro's Servant Hang him, he'll abuse us.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Isidore's Servant A plague upon him, dog!

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Varro's Servant How dost, fool?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Dost dialogue with thy shadow?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Varro's Servant I speak not to thee.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No,'tis to thyself.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To the Fool

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Come away.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Isidore's Servant There's the fool hangs on your back already.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No, thou stand'st single, thou'rt not on him yet.

speaker: CAPHIS
text_entry: Where's the fool now?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: He last asked the question. Poor rogues, and

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: usurers' men! bawds between gold and want!

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: What are we, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Asses.

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Why?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That you ask me what you are, and do not know

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: yourselves. Speak to 'em, fool.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: How do you, gentlemen?

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Gramercies, good fool: how does your mistress?

speaker: Fool
text_entry: She's e'en setting on water to scald such chickens

speaker: Fool
text_entry: as you are. Would we could see you at Corinth!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Good! gramercy.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Enter Page

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Look you, here comes my mistress' page.

speaker: Page
text_entry: [To the Fool]  Why, how now, captain! what do you

speaker: Page
text_entry: in this wise company? How dost thou, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Would I had a rod in my mouth, that I might answer

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: thee profitably.

speaker: Page
text_entry: Prithee, Apemantus, read me the superscription of

speaker: Page
text_entry: these letters: I know not which is which.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Canst not read?

speaker: Page
text_entry: No.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: There will little learning die then, that day thou

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: art hanged. This is to Lord Timon; this to

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Alcibiades. Go; thou wast born a bastard, and thou't

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: die a bawd.

speaker: Page
text_entry: Thou wast whelped a dog, and thou shalt famish a

speaker: Page
text_entry: dog's death. Answer not; I am gone.

speaker: Page
text_entry: Exit

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: E'en so thou outrunnest grace. Fool, I will go with

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: you to Lord Timon's.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Will you leave me there?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: If Timon stay at home. You three serve three usurers?

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Ay; would they served us!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: So would I,--as good a trick as ever hangman served thief.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Are you three usurers' men?

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Ay, fool.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: I think no usurer but has a fool to his servant: my

speaker: Fool
text_entry: mistress is one, and I am her fool. When men come

speaker: Fool
text_entry: to borrow of your masters, they approach sadly, and

speaker: Fool
text_entry: go away merry; but they enter my mistress' house

speaker: Fool
text_entry: merrily, and go away sadly: the reason of this?

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Varro's Servant I could render one.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Do it then, that we may account thee a whoremaster

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: and a knave; which not-withstanding, thou shalt be

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: no less esteemed.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Varro's Servant What is a whoremaster, fool?

speaker: Fool
text_entry: A fool in good clothes, and something like thee.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: 'Tis a spirit: sometime't appears like a lord;

speaker: Fool
text_entry: sometime like a lawyer; sometime like a philosopher,

speaker: Fool
text_entry: with two stones moe than's artificial one: he is

speaker: Fool
text_entry: very often like a knight; and, generally, in all

speaker: Fool
text_entry: shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore

speaker: Fool
text_entry: to thirteen, this spirit walks in.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Varro's Servant Thou art not altogether a fool.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Nor thou altogether a wise man: as much foolery as

speaker: Fool
text_entry: I have, so much wit thou lackest.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That answer might have become Apemantus.

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Aside, aside; here comes Lord Timon.

speaker: All Servants
text_entry: Re-enter TIMON and FLAVIUS

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Come with me, fool, come.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: I do not always follow lover, elder brother and

speaker: Fool
text_entry: woman; sometime the philosopher.

speaker: Fool
text_entry: Exeunt APEMANTUS and Fool

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Pray you, walk near: I'll speak with you anon.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exeunt Servants

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You make me marvel: wherefore ere this time

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Had you not fully laid my state before me,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That I might so have rated my expense,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: As I had leave of means?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: You would not hear me,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: At many leisures I proposed.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go to:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Perchance some single vantages you took.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: When my indispos ition put you back:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And that unaptness made your minister,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thus to excuse yourself.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: O my good lord,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: At many times I brought in my accounts,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Laid them before you; you would throw them off,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And say, you found them in mine honesty.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: When, for some trifling present, you have bid me

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Return so much, I have shook my head and wept;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Yea, 'gainst the authority of manners, pray'd you

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To hold your hand more close: I did endure

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Not seldom, nor no slight cheques, when I have

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Prompted you in the ebb of your estate

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And your great flow of debts. My loved lord,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Though you hear now, too late--yet now's a time--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The greatest of your having lacks a half

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To pay your present debts.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Let all my land be sold.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: 'Tis all engaged, some forfeited and gone;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And what remains will hardly stop the mouth

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Of present dues: the future comes apace:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: What shall defend the interim? and at length

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: How goes our reckoning?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To Lacedaemon did my land extend.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: O my good lord, the world is but a word:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Were it all yours to give it in a breath,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: How quickly were it gone!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You tell me true.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: If you suspect my husbandry or falsehood,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Call me before the exactest auditors

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And set me on the proof. So the gods bless me,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: When all our offices have been oppress'd

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: With drunken spilth of wine, when every room

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Hath blazed with lights and bray'd with minstrelsy,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I have retired me to a wasteful cock,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And set mine eyes at flow.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Prithee, no more.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Heavens, have I said, the bounty of this lord!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: This night englutted! Who is not Timon's?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: What heart, head, sword, force, means, but is

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Lord Timon's?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Great Timon, noble, worthy, royal Timon!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Ah, when the means are gone that buy this praise,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The breath is gone whereof this praise is made:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Feast-won, fast-lost; one cloud of winter showers,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: These flies are couch'd.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Come, sermon me no further:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: No villanous bounty yet hath pass'd my heart;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Unwisely, not ignobly, have I given.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To think I shall lack friends? Secure thy heart;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If I would broach the vessels of my love,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And try the argument of hearts by borrowing,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Men and men's fortunes could I frankly use

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: As I can bid thee speak.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Assurance bless your thoughts!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And, in some sort, these wants of mine are crown'd,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That I account them blessings; for by these

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Shall I try friends: you shall perceive how you

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Mistake my fortunes; I am wealthy in my friends.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Within there! Flaminius! Servilius!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other Servants

speaker: Servants
text_entry: My lord? my lord?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I will dispatch you severally; you to Lord Lucius;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: to Lord Lucullus you: I hunted with his honour

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: to-day: you, to Sempronius: commend me to their

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: loves, and, I am proud, say, that my occasions have

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: found time to use 'em toward a supply of money: let

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: the request be fifty talents.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: As you have said, my lord.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: [Aside]  Lord Lucius and Lucullus? hum!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go you, sir, to the senators--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Of whom, even to the state's best health, I have

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Deserved this hearing--bid 'em send o' the instant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A thousand talents to me.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I have been bold--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: For that I knew it the most general way--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To them to use your signet and your name;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: But they do shake their heads, and I am here

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: No richer in return.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Is't true? can't be?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: They answer, in a joint and corporate voice,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Do what they would; are sorry--you are honourable,--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: But yet they could have wish'd--they know not--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Something hath been amiss--a noble nature

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: May catch a wrench--would all were well--'tis pity;--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And so, intending other serious matters,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: After distasteful looks and these hard fractions,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: With certain half-caps and cold-moving nods

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: They froze me into silence.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You gods, reward them!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Prithee, man, look cheerly. These old fellows

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Have their ingratitude in them hereditary:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Their blood is caked, 'tis cold, it seldom flows;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: 'Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And nature, as it grows again toward earth,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Is fashion'd for the journey, dull and heavy.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To a Servant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go to Ventidius.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To FLAVIUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Prithee, be not sad,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou art true and honest; ingeniously I speak.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: No blame belongs to thee.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To Servant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ventidius lately

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Buried his father; by whose death he's stepp'd

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Into a great estate: when he was poor,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Imprison'd and in scarcity of friends,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I clear'd him with five talents: greet him from me;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Bid him suppose some good necessity

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Touches his friend, which craves to be remember'd

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: With those five talents.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit Servant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To FLAVIUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That had, give't these fellows

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To whom 'tis instant due. Ne'er speak, or think,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That Timon's fortunes 'mong his friends can sink.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I would I could not think it: that thought is

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: bounty's foe;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Being free itself, it thinks all others so.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: SCENE I. A room in Lucullus' house.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: FLAMINIUS waiting. Enter a Servant to him

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I have told my lord of you; he is coming down to you.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: I thank you, sir.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Enter LUCULLUS

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Here's my lord.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: [Aside]  One of Lord Timon's men? a gift, I

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: warrant. Why, this hits right; I dreamt of a silver

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: basin and ewer to-night. Flaminius, honest

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: Flaminius; you are very respectively welcome, sir.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: Fill me some wine.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: Exit Servants

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: And how does that honourable, complete, free-hearted

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: gentleman of Athens, thy very bountiful good lord

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: and master?

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: His health is well sir.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: I am right glad that his health is well, sir: and

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: what hast thou there under thy cloak, pretty Flaminius?

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: 'Faith, nothing but an empty box, sir; which, in my

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: lord's behalf, I come to entreat your honour to

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: supply; who, having great and instant occasion to

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: use fifty talents, hath sent to your lordship to

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: furnish him, nothing doubting your present

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: assistance therein.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: La, la, la, la! 'nothing doubting,' says he? Alas,

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: good lord! a noble gentleman 'tis, if he would not

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: keep so good a house. Many a time and often I ha'

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: dined with him, and told him on't, and come again to

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: supper to him, of purpose to have him spend less,

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: and yet he would embrace no counsel, take no warning

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: by my coming. Every man has his fault, and honesty

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: is his: I ha' told him on't, but I could ne'er get

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: him from't.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: Re-enter Servant, with wine

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Please your lordship, here is the wine.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: Flaminius, I have noted thee always wise. Here's to thee.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Your lordship speaks your pleasure.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: I have observed thee always for a towardly prompt

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: spirit--give thee thy due--and one that knows what

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: belongs to reason; and canst use the time well, if

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: the time use thee well: good parts in thee.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: To Servant

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: Get you gone, sirrah.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: Exit Servant

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: Draw nearer, honest Flaminius. Thy lord's a

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: bountiful gentleman: but thou art wise; and thou

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: knowest well enough, although thou comest to me,

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: that this is no time to lend money, especially upon

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: bare friendship, without security. Here's three

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: solidares for thee: good boy, wink at me, and say

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: thou sawest me not. Fare thee well.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Is't possible the world should so much differ,

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: And we alive that lived? Fly, damned baseness,

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: To him that worships thee!

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Throwing the money back

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: Ha! now I see thou art a fool, and fit for thy master.

speaker: LUCULLUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: May these add to the number that may scald thee!

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Let moulten coin be thy damnation,

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Thou disease of a friend, and not himself!

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Has friendship such a faint and milky heart,

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: It turns in less than two nights? O you gods,

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: I feel master's passion! this slave,

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Unto his honour, has my lord's meat in him:

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment,

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: When he is turn'd to poison?

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: O, may diseases only work upon't!

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: And, when he's sick to death, let not that part of nature

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Which my lord paid for, be of any power

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: To expel sickness, but prolong his hour!

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. A public place.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Enter LUCILIUS, with three Strangers

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Who, the Lord Timon? he is my very good friend, and

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: an honourable gentleman.

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: We know him for no less, though we are but strangers

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: to him. But I can tell you one thing, my lord, and

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: which I hear from common rumours: now Lord Timon's

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: happy hours are done and past, and his estate

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: shrinks from him.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Fie, no, do not believe it; he cannot want for money.

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: But believe you this, my lord, that, not long ago,

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: one of his men was with the Lord Lucullus to borrow

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: so many talents, nay, urged extremely for't and

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: showed what necessity belonged to't, and yet was denied.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: How!

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: I tell you, denied, my lord.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: What a strange case was that! now, before the gods,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: I am ashamed on't. Denied that honourable man!

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: there was very little honour showed in't. For my own

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: part, I must needs confess, I have received some

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: small kindnesses from him, as money, plate, jewels

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: and such-like trifles, nothing comparing to his;

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: yet, had he mistook him and sent to me, I should

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: ne'er have denied his occasion so many talents.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Enter SERVILIUS

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: See, by good hap, yonder's my lord;

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: I have sweat to see his honour. My honoured lord,--

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: To LUCIUS

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Servilius! you are kindly met, sir. Fare thee well:

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: commend me to thy honourable virtuous lord, my very

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: exquisite friend.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: May it please your honour, my lord hath sent--

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Ha! what has he sent? I am so much endeared to

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: that lord; he's ever sending: how shall I thank

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: him, thinkest thou? And what has he sent now?

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: Has only sent his present occasion now, my lord;

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: requesting your lordship to supply his instant use

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: with so many talents.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: I know his lordship is but merry with me;

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: He cannot want fifty five hundred talents.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: But in the mean time he wants less, my lord.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: If his occasion were not virtuous,

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: I should not urge it half so faithfully.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Dost thou speak seriously, Servilius?

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: Upon my soul,'tis true, sir.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish myself

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: against such a good time, when I might ha' shown

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: myself honourable! how unluckily it happened, that I

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: should purchase the day before for a little part,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: and undo a great deal of honoured! Servilius, now,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: before the gods, I am not able to do,--the more

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: beast, I say:--I was sending to use Lord Timon

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: myself, these gentlemen can witness! but I would

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: not, for the wealth of Athens, I had done't now.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Commend me bountifully to his good lordship; and I

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: hope his honour will conceive the fairest of me,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: because I have no power to be kind: and tell him

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: this from me, I count it one of my greatest

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: afflictions, say, that I cannot pleasure such an

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: honourable gentleman. Good Servilius, will you

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: befriend me so far, as to use mine own words to him?

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: Yes, sir, I shall.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: I'll look you out a good turn, Servilius.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Exit SERVILIUS

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: True as you said, Timon is shrunk indeed;

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: And he that's once denied will hardly speed.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Do you observe this, Hostilius?

speaker: Second Stranger
text_entry: Ay, too well.

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Why, this is the world's soul; and just of the

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: same piece

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Is every flatterer's spirit. Who can call him

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: His friend that dips in the same dish? for, in

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: My knowing, Timon has been this lord's father,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: And kept his credit with his purse,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Supported his estate; nay, Timon's money

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Has paid his men their wages: he ne'er drinks,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: But Timon's silver treads upon his lip;

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: And yet--O, see the monstrousness of man

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: When he looks out in an ungrateful shape!--

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: He does deny him, in respect of his,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: What charitable men afford to beggars.

speaker: Third Stranger
text_entry: Religion groans at it.

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: For mine own part,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: I never tasted Timon in my life,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Nor came any of his bounties over me,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: To mark me for his friend; yet, I protest,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: For his right noble mind, illustrious virtue

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: And honourable carriage,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Had his necessity made use of me,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: I would have put my wealth into donation,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: And the best half should have return'd to him,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: So much I love his heart: but, I perceive,

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Men must learn now with pity to dispense;

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: For policy sits above conscience.

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: SCENE III. A room in Sempronius' house.

speaker: First Stranger
text_entry: Enter SEMPRONIUS, and a Servant of TIMON's

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: Must he needs trouble me in 't,--hum!--'bove

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: all others?

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: He might have tried Lord Lucius or Lucullus;

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: And now Ventidius is wealthy too,

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: Whom he redeem'd from prison: all these

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: Owe their estates unto him.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: My lord,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: They have all been touch'd and found base metal, for

speaker: Servant
text_entry: They have au denied him.

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: How! have they denied him?

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: Has Ventidius and Lucullus denied him?

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: And does he send to me? Three? hum!

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: It shows but little love or judgment in him:

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: Must I be his last refuge! His friends, like

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: physicians,

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: Thrive, give him over: must I take the cure upon me?

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: Has much disgraced me in't; I'm angry at him,

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: That might have known my place: I see no sense for't,

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: But his occasion might have woo'd me first;

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: For, in my conscience, I was the first man

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: That e'er received gift from him:

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: And does he think so backwardly of me now,

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: That I'll requite its last? No:

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: So it may prove an argument of laughter

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: To the rest, and 'mongst lords I be thought a fool.

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: I'ld rather than the worth of thrice the sum,

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: Had sent to me first, but for my mind's sake;

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: I'd such a courage to do him good. But now return,

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: And with their faint reply this answer join;

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: Who bates mine honour shall not know my coin.

speaker: SEMPRONIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Excellent! Your lordship's a goodly villain. The

speaker: Servant
text_entry: devil knew not what he did when he made man

speaker: Servant
text_entry: politic; he crossed himself by 't: and I cannot

speaker: Servant
text_entry: think but, in the end, the villainies of man will

speaker: Servant
text_entry: set him clear. How fairly this lord strives to

speaker: Servant
text_entry: appear foul! takes virtuous copies to be wicked,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: like those that under hot ardent zeal would set

speaker: Servant
text_entry: whole realms on fire: Of such a nature is his

speaker: Servant
text_entry: politic love.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: This was my lord's best hope; now all are fled,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Save only the gods: now his friends are dead,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Doors, that were ne'er acquainted with their wards

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Many a bounteous year must be employ'd

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Now to guard sure their master.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: And this is all a liberal course allows;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Who cannot keep his wealth must keep his house.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Servant
text_entry: SCENE IV. The same. A hall in Timon's house.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Enter two Servants of Varro, and the Servant of  LUCIUS, meeting TITUS, HORTENSIUS, and other Servants of TIMON's creditors, waiting his coming out

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Varro's

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Well met; good morrow, Titus and Hortensius.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: The like to you kind Varro.

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: Lucius!

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: What, do we meet together?

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Ay, and I think

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: One business does command us all; for mine Is money.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: So is theirs and ours.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: Enter PHILOTUS

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant And Sir Philotus too!

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: Good day at once.

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant                   Welcome, good brother.

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: What do you think the hour?

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: Labouring for nine.

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant So much?

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: Is not my lord seen yet?

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Not yet.

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: I wonder on't; he was wont to shine at seven.

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Ay, but the days are wax'd shorter with him:

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: You must consider that a prodigal course

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: Is like the sun's; but not, like his, recoverable.

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: I fear 'tis deepest winter in Lord Timon's purse;

speaker: PHILOTUS
