text_entry: That is one may reach deep enough, and yet

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: Find little.

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: I am of your fear for that.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: I'll show you how to observe a strange event.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: Your lord sends now for money.

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: Most true, he does.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: And he wears jewels now of Timon's gift,

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: For which I wait for money.

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: It is against my heart.

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Mark, how strange it shows,

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: Timon in this should pay more than he owes:

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: And e'en as if your lord should wear rich jewels,

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: And send for money for 'em.

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: I'm weary of this charge, the gods can witness:

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: I know my lord hath spent of Timon's wealth,

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth.

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: Varro's

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Yes, mine's three thousand crowns: what's yours?

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Five thousand mine.

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Varro's

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: 'Tis much deep: and it should seem by the sun,

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Your master's confidence was above mine;

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Else, surely, his had equall'd.

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Enter FLAMINIUS.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: One of Lord Timon's men.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Flaminius! Sir, a word: pray, is my lord ready to

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: come forth?

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: No, indeed, he is not.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: We attend his lordship; pray, signify so much.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: I need not tell him that; he knows you are too diligent.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Ha! is not that his steward muffled so?

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: He goes away in a cloud: call him, call him.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: Do you hear, sir?

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: Varro's

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: By your leave, sir,--

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: What do ye ask of me, my friend?

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: We wait for certain money here, sir.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Ay,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: If money were as certain as your waiting,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: 'Twere sure enough.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Why then preferr'd you not your sums and bills,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: When your false masters eat of my lord's meat?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Then they could smile and fawn upon his debts

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And take down the interest into their

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: gluttonous maws.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Let me pass quietly:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Believe 't, my lord and I have made an end;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I have no more to reckon, he to spend.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Ay, but this answer will not serve.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: If 'twill not serve,'tis not so base as you;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: For you serve knaves.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Varro's

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: How! what does his cashiered worship mutter?

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Varro's

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: No matter what; he's poor, and that's revenge

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: enough. Who can speak broader than he that has no

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: house to put his head in? such may rail against

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: great buildings.

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Enter SERVILIUS

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: O, here's Servilius; now we shall know some answer.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair some

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: other hour, I should derive much from't; for,

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: take't of my soul, my lord leans wondrously to

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: discontent: his comfortable temper has forsook him;

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: he's much out of health, and keeps his chamber.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant: Many do keep their chambers are not sick:

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: And, if it be so far beyond his health,

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: Methinks he should the sooner pay his debts,

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: And make a clear way to the gods.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text_entry: Good gods!

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: We cannot take this for answer, sir.

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: [Within]  Servilius, help! My lord! my lord!

speaker: FLAMINIUS
text_entry: Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What, are my doors opposed against my passage?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Have I been ever free, and must my house

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be my retentive enemy, my gaol?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The place which I have feasted, does it now,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Like all mankind, show me an iron heart?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Put in now, Titus.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: My lord, here is my bill.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Here's mine.

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: And mine, my lord.

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: Both

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: Varro's Servants And ours, my lord.

speaker: PHILOTUS
text_entry: All our bills.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Knock me down with 'em: cleave me to the girdle.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Alas, my lord,-

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Cut my heart in sums.

speaker: TITUS
text_entry: Mine, fifty talents.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Tell out my blood.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Lucilius' Servant Five thousand crowns, my lord.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Five thousand drops pays that.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What yours?--and yours?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Varro's

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: My lord,--

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Varro's

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: My lord,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: 'Faith, I perceive our masters may throw their caps

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: at their money: these debts may well be called

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: desperate ones, for a madman owes 'em.

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HORTENSIUS
text_entry: Re-enter TIMON and FLAVIUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They have e'en put my breath from me, the slaves.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Creditors? devils!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: My dear lord,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What if it should be so?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: My lord,--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll have it so. My steward!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Here, my lord.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: So fitly? Go, bid all my friends again,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: All, sirrah, all:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll once more feast the rascals.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: O my lord,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: You only speak from your distracted soul;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: There is not so much left, to furnish out

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: A moderate table.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be't not in thy care; go,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I charge thee, invite them all: let in the tide

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Of knaves once more; my cook and I'll provide.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: SCENE V. The same. The senate-house. The Senate sitting.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: My lord, you have my voice to it; the fault's

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Bloody; 'tis necessary he should die:

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Nothing emboldens sin so much as mercy.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Most true; the law shall bruise him.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Enter ALCIBIADES, with Attendants

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Honour, health, and compassion to the senate!

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Now, captain?

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: I am an humble suitor to your virtues;

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: For pity is the virtue of the law,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: And none but tyrants use it cruelly.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: It pleases time and fortune to lie heavy

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Upon a friend of mine, who, in hot blood,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Hath stepp'd into the law, which is past depth

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: To those that, without heed, do plunge into 't.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: He is a man, setting his fate aside,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Of comely virtues:

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Nor did he soil the fact with cowardice--

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: An honour in him which buys out his fault--

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: But with a noble fury and fair spirit,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Seeing his reputation touch'd to death,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: He did oppose his foe:

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: And with such sober and unnoted passion

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: He did behave his anger, ere 'twas spent,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: As if he had but proved an argument.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: You undergo too strict a paradox,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Striving to make an ugly deed look fair:

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Your words have took such pains as if they labour'd

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: To bring manslaughter into form and set quarrelling

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Upon the head of valour; which indeed

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Is valour misbegot and came into the world

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: When sects and factions were newly born:

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: He's truly valiant that can wisely suffer

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: The worst that man can breathe, and make his wrongs

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: His outsides, to wear them like his raiment,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: carelessly,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: And ne'er prefer his injuries to his heart,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: To bring it into danger.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: If wrongs be evils and enforce us kill,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: What folly 'tis to hazard life for ill!

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: My lord,--

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: You cannot make gross sins look clear:

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: To revenge is no valour, but to bear.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: My lords, then, under favour, pardon me,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: If I speak like a captain.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Why do fond men expose themselves to battle,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: And not endure all threats? sleep upon't,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: And let the foes quietly cut their throats,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Without repugnancy? If there be

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Such valour in the bearing, what make we

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Abroad? why then, women are more valiant

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: That stay at home, if bearing carry it,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: And the ass more captain than the lion, the felon

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Loaden with irons wiser than the judge,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: If wisdom be in suffering. O my lords,

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: As you are great, be pitifully good:

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Who cannot condemn rashness in cold blood?

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: To kill, I grant, is sin's extremest gust;

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: But, in defence, by mercy, 'tis most just.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: To be in anger is impiety;

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: But who is man that is not angry?

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Weigh but the crime with this.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: You breathe in vain.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: In vain! his service done

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: At Lacedaemon and Byzantium

speaker: ALCIBIADES

text_entry: Therefore, so please thee to return with us

text_entry: Why, I was writing of my epitaph;
